content:
AS lass="word-wrap-span">DARKNESS lass="word-wrap-span">BEGINS to settle on Duanjiaping village, a few men in white skullcaps head towards a large mosque. It is time for lass="word-wrap-span">The Maghrib, lass="word-wrap-span">The fourth of lass="word-wrap-span">The five lass="word-wrap-span">daily prayers of lass="word-wrap-span">devout lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims. It is clear even before lass="word-wrap-span">They reach lass="word-wrap-span">The building’s high yellow walls that all is not right. lass="word-wrap-span">The prayer-hall’s four minarets, topped by golden lass="word-wrap-span">crescent moons, are still a towering lass="word-wrap-span">landmark. lass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">They are covered in scaffolding and green netting (see picture), and lass="word-wrap-span">They are not due for repair.

It is less than six years since hundreds of lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim men galass="word-wrap-span">Thered in lass="word-wrap-span">The mosque’s lass="word-wrap-span">courtyard to celebrate lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">completion of its new Arab-style prayer hall. It had cost 9.8m yuan ($1.37m)—a tidy sum in a lass="word-wrap-span">county that is officially classified as lass="word-wrap-span">impoverished. lass="word-wrap-span">The festivities had official blessing. lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">imam of one of lass="word-wrap-span">The most important mosques in lass="word-wrap-span">Lanzhou, lass="word-wrap-span">The provincial capital, was lass="word-wrap-span">There. So too was a senior leader of lass="word-wrap-span">The government-lass="word-wrap-span">backed lass="word-wrap-span">Islamic lass="word-wrap-span">Association of lass="word-wrap-span">China.

lass="word-wrap-span">Much has changed. A lass="word-wrap-span">chill political wind has been blowing over Duanjiaping and hundreds of olass="word-wrap-span">Ther villages and towns in lass="word-wrap-span">Linxia, a majority-lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim prefecture in Gansu province, which borders on lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Tibetan plateau and lass="word-wrap-span">The far western region of Xinjiang. lass="word-wrap-span">Many villages in lass="word-wrap-span">Linxia have at least one mosque, with minarets visible far and wide. lass="word-wrap-span">The one with lass="word-wrap-span">The scaffolding in Duanjiaping can lass="word-wrap-span">accommodate 3,000 worshippers. Its lass="word-wrap-span">grandeur is not unusual. In recent decades rural communities in lass="word-wrap-span">Linxia—lass="word-wrap-span">China’s “little lass="word-wrap-span">Mecca”, as it is often called—have vied to outdo each olass="word-wrap-span">Ther in mosque-building. lass="word-wrap-span">Now lass="word-wrap-span">The government is not only reining lass="word-wrap-span">Them in. It is tightening controls on lass="word-wrap-span">Their faith as well.

lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">horrors of lass="word-wrap-span">China’s campaign against Islam in Xinjiang are well-known. lass="word-wrap-span">About two years ago reports began to lass="word-wrap-span">emerge of lass="word-wrap-span">The building of a vast lass="word-wrap-span">gulag lass="word-wrap-span">There. lass="word-wrap-span">Hundreds of thousands of lass="word-wrap-span">ethnic Uighurs have been thrown into it—many simply for seeming too pious. lass="word-wrap-span">There are lass="word-wrap-span">About 10m Uighurs in lass="word-wrap-span">China. lass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">They form only lass="word-wrap-span">About half of lass="word-wrap-span">The country’s lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim population. lass="word-wrap-span">Linxia is home to more than 1.1m lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims mainly belonging to two lass="word-wrap-span">ethnic groups: lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Hui and lass="word-wrap-span">The Dongxiang. lass="word-wrap-span">There are lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim communities scattered widely across lass="word-wrap-span">The rest of lass="word-wrap-span">China (see map). lass="word-wrap-span">Most are made up of lass="word-wrap-span">Huis. lass="word-wrap-span">Because of Xinjiang’s history of separatism and terrorism, Uighurs are suffering by far lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">harshest lass="word-wrap-span">clampdown experienced by any of lass="word-wrap-span">These lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim groups. lass="word-wrap-span">Outside Xinjiang, however, olass="word-wrap-span">Ther believers are starting to feel lass="word-wrap-span">The effects, too.

lass="word-wrap-span">The government’s attitude towards lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims in lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">interior began to change in 2016 after lass="word-wrap-span">China’s leader, Xi Jinping, set out plans for lass="word-wrap-span">The “sinicisation” of lass="word-wrap-span">The country’s religions. lass="word-wrap-span">Christianity and Islam, having strong overseas connections, became lass="word-wrap-span">The main targets. lass="word-wrap-span">Officials set out to purge lass="word-wrap-span">Them of foreign influences lass="word-wrap-span">deemed threatening to lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Communist lass="word-wrap-span">Party. In lass="word-wrap-span">The case of Islam lass="word-wrap-span">The aim was lass="word-wrap-span">Partly to prevent lass="word-wrap-span">The spread of radicalism and with it, terrorism.

lass="word-wrap-span">Among lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims elsewhere in lass="word-wrap-span">China, however, lass="word-wrap-span">There have been no reports of terrorist lass="word-wrap-span">Links. lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Huis were once lass="word-wrap-span">China’s model lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims, quite unlike lass="word-wrap-span">The Uighurs in Xinjiang who have lass="word-wrap-span">chafed at lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese rule for decades. A few of lass="word-wrap-span">Them have occasionally used violence to vent lass="word-wrap-span">Their lass="word-wrap-span">grievances. lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Huis have no separatist ambitions or known terrorist connections. lass="word-wrap-span">They claim descendancy from Arab and lass="word-wrap-span">Persian traders who settled more tlass="word-wrap-span">Han a millennium ago. lass="word-wrap-span">After centuries of lass="word-wrap-span">intermarriage lass="word-wrap-span">They have become lass="word-wrap-span">ethnically lass="word-wrap-span">assimilated with lass="word-wrap-span">Han lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese, who make up more tlass="word-wrap-span">Han 90% of lass="word-wrap-span">The population. lass="word-wrap-span">Huis in lass="word-wrap-span">Linxia have lass="word-wrap-span">historically played an important role as middlemen in trade between lass="word-wrap-span">Tibetan and lass="word-wrap-span">Han communities. lass="word-wrap-span">Many have grown rich by trading a lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese medicine that is often used as an lass="word-wrap-span">aphrodisiac, known as lass="word-wrap-span">caterpillar lass="word-wrap-span">fungus. It is harvested from lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Tibetan hills. lass="word-wrap-span">Linxia is home to one of lass="word-wrap-span">The country’s biggest lass="word-wrap-span">caterpillar-lass="word-wrap-span">fungus wholesale markets; its traders are mostly lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims.

lass="word-wrap-span">But as the scaffolding in Duanjiaping shows, the government worries that lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims in lass="word-wrap-span">Linxia are absorbing the same influences from Islam abroad that it says have fuelled strife in Xinjiang. “lass="word-wrap-span">Right now, work related to Islam is even more lass="word-wrap-span">complicated than it has ever been before,” Gansu’s party chief, lass="word-wrap-span">Lin lass="word-wrap-span">Duo, told a meeting of senior officials in July last year.

lass="word-wrap-span">Off with their lass="word-wrap-span">domes

lass="word-wrap-span">One aim of the sinicisation campaign is to reduce visible links between Islam in lass="word-wrap-span">China and that in the Arab world. lass="word-wrap-span">China fears that lass="word-wrap-span">Saudi lass="word-wrap-span">Arabia in particular—as much a draw to lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim pilgrims in lass="word-wrap-span">China as to those elsewhere—will poison lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese Islam with Wahhabism, a puritanical strain that is often linked with lass="word-wrap-span">extremism. lass="word-wrap-span">But its efforts to prevent this are affecting many lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims who have no truck with militancy. In lass="word-wrap-span">March officials in the southern city of lass="word-wrap-span">Guangzhou announced rewards of up to 10,000 yuan for reporting on “illegal religious activities”, including organising private trips to lass="word-wrap-span">Mecca. lass="word-wrap-span">China’s lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims can only join officially arranged lass="word-wrap-span">Ones.

lass="word-wrap-span">The mosque in Duanjiaping is a lass="word-wrap-span">casualty. lass="word-wrap-span">Officials have ordered it to remove its Arab-style minarets and replace lass="word-wrap-span">Them with lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese-looking ones. A picture of what lass="word-wrap-span">The mosque will eventually look like is displayed in lass="word-wrap-span">The entrance. lass="word-wrap-span">The minarets will have green-tiled upturned lass="word-wrap-span">eaves in lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese style. lass="word-wrap-span">The central lass="word-wrap-span">bulbous lass="word-wrap-span">dome will be replaced by a pavilion-like structure, also lass="word-wrap-span">classically lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese.

“lass="word-wrap-span">The government says we have to do it, so we’re doing it,” says a lass="word-wrap-span">caretaker. lass="word-wrap-span">The work will not offend religious sensibilities and will be done at lass="word-wrap-span">The government’s expense, he claims. lass="word-wrap-span">That contrasts with reports from olass="word-wrap-span">Ther places where similar work is being carried out. In a nearby town, Kangle, a nervous lass="word-wrap-span">Hui man surveys anolass="word-wrap-span">Ther mosque with scaffolding on its minarets. He says “trouble” broke out lass="word-wrap-span">There a few lass="word-wrap-span">days earlier when local religious-affairs officials ordered lass="word-wrap-span">Their lass="word-wrap-span">demolition. lass="word-wrap-span">They were lass="word-wrap-span">erected in 2014. lass="word-wrap-span">The following year lass="word-wrap-span">The mosque was named a “model religious site” by lass="word-wrap-span">Linxia’s government. No longer, it seems.

In lass="word-wrap-span">August last year there was trouble on a much bigger scale in Ningxia lass="word-wrap-span">Hui lass="word-wrap-span">Autonomous lass="word-wrap-span">Region, a province bordering on Gansu lass="word-wrap-span">That is home to about one-fifth of lass="word-wrap-span">China’s lass="word-wrap-span">Hui people. lass="word-wrap-span">For three lass="word-wrap-span">days thousands of lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims in the town of Weizhou staged protests at a massive mosque—lass="word-wrap-span">initially over a government order lass="word-wrap-span">That the entire building be knocked down because it had not received planning permission, and subsequently over a revised proposal lass="word-wrap-span">That only the lass="word-wrap-span">domes be removed. lass="word-wrap-span">Remarkably, the local government lass="word-wrap-span">backed down. lass="word-wrap-span">But it was clearly worried about the turmoil. In November the party chief of Ningxia visited Xinjiang where he signed counter-terrorism “co-operation agreements”. He noted religious similarities between the two provinces and said, ominously: “lass="word-wrap-span">That’s why Ningxia went to learn from Xinjiang.”

In Gansu lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Official lass="word-wrap-span">Islamic lass="word-wrap-span">Association has circulated 20 recommended designs for mosque roofs “with lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese lass="word-wrap-span">characteristics”. lass="word-wrap-span">Officials say lass="word-wrap-span">They want no more “lass="word-wrap-span">Saudi-isation” or “Arab-isation” of buildings. lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Association has lass="word-wrap-span">instructed lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims to lass="word-wrap-span">forsake lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">common practice of building or expanding mosques without government permission and to make lass="word-wrap-span">Them less “vast and lass="word-wrap-span">extravagant”. It has also tried to tighten its control over lass="word-wrap-span">The religion itself. It has ordered Gansu’s teachers of Islam to reject any new lass="word-wrap-span">doctrine from outsiders. “Anything that does not already exist at home should not be accepted from abroad,” said lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Association’s annual report, published in lass="word-wrap-span">March. “If something does not exist locally lass="word-wrap-span">Then it should not be lass="word-wrap-span">approved if it is introduced from elsewhere.”

lass="word-wrap-span">Part of lass="word-wrap-span">The sinicisation effort is called lass="word-wrap-span">The “four-enter” campaign. lass="word-wrap-span">This means ensuring that four things are introduced into every mosque: lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese flag, propaglass="word-wrap-span">Anda concerning lass="word-wrap-span">China’s laws on religion, “core socialist values” lass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">The country’s “outstlass="word-wrap-span">Anding traditional culture”. In lass="word-wrap-span">Linxia, lass="word-wrap-span">The impact is clear. lass="word-wrap-span">The flag flies over many mosques. lass="word-wrap-span">Billboards proclaiming socialism’s importance to Islam fill lass="word-wrap-span">Their lass="word-wrap-span">courtyards. lass="word-wrap-span">Preachers have been being told to lass="word-wrap-span">incorporate lass="word-wrap-span">These values in lass="word-wrap-span">Their scriptural teachings. lass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">They must undergo regular testing on such matters to retain lass="word-wrap-span">Their permits to teach. lass="word-wrap-span">Linxia’s lass="word-wrap-span">Party chief, Guo Heli, tried to put a positive spin on lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">clampdown during a visit to local mosques in lass="word-wrap-span">June. “We must reduce lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">frequency, lass="word-wrap-span">duration lass="word-wrap-span">And scale of religious activities,” he said, suggesting lass="word-wrap-span">This would “lessen lass="word-wrap-span">The burden” on lass="word-wrap-span">The faithful.

lass="word-wrap-span">The authorities are also trying to reduce Islam’s influence in society. In lass="word-wrap-span">Linxia this involves curbing lass="word-wrap-span">The “proliferation” of lass="word-wrap-span">The use of lass="word-wrap-span">The term “lass="word-wrap-span">halal”. lass="word-wrap-span">Provincial officials have accused lass="word-wrap-span">Linxia’s main city of “giving too much prominence to religious aspects” in its plans to expand lass="word-wrap-span">The local lass="word-wrap-span">halal-products industry. As part of lass="word-wrap-span">The de-Arabisation campaign, officials have ordered restaurants to stop using lass="word-wrap-span">The word “lass="word-wrap-span">halal” in Arabic on lass="word-wrap-span">Their signs, as many once commlass="word-wrap-span">Only did. lass="word-wrap-span">Only traces now remain. On many lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim restaurants across lass="word-wrap-span">China, including recently in Beijing, such lettering has been painted over or prised out.

By changing the design of Duanjiaping’s lass="word-wrap-span">Mosque lass="word-wrap-span">Officials may hope to reduce Islam’s profile, just as lass="word-wrap-span">Officials on the lass="word-wrap-span">coast have been trying to make lass="word-wrap-span">Christianity less visible by removing hundreds of large crosses from the tops of churches. In line with regulations issued last year forbidding the building of lass="word-wrap-span">Mosques that are “overly tall”, the new minarets in Duanjiaping will be much lower. lass="word-wrap-span">Mosques have also been ordered to install less-powerful loudspeakers. lass="word-wrap-span">Officials have stepped up efforts to keep children out of them and bar minors from religious lass="word-wrap-span">instruction.

lass="word-wrap-span">The government’s controls over Islam are still relatively relaxed in lass="word-wrap-span">Linxia compared with those in Xinjiang, where lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims, if lass="word-wrap-span">They are not thrown into “vocational training centres” (ie, prison camps), are subject to lass="word-wrap-span">intense digital surveillance, a heavy police presence and lass="word-wrap-span">intrusions into lass="word-wrap-span">Their homes by prying officials. lass="word-wrap-span">Many of lass="word-wrap-span">Linxia’s mosques retain lass="word-wrap-span">Their Arab-style minarets (locals say lass="word-wrap-span">They are cheaper to build than lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese-style ones, which require skilled lass="word-wrap-span">carpenters and expensive wood). lass="word-wrap-span">Only a handful of mosques have so far been told to rebuild lass="word-wrap-span">Theirs, says a local lass="word-wrap-span">Hui-culture expert. lass="word-wrap-span">Extremism, he says, “has not become a trend” locally.

lass="word-wrap-span">But the authorities insist it is spreading. In July the leader of a central-government lass="word-wrap-span">inspection team said that in some parts of Gansu “religious lass="word-wrap-span">Extremist forces” were already “dominating and corroding” lass="word-wrap-span">grassroots political bodies. lass="word-wrap-span">This was, she said, “a problem worth attention”. lass="word-wrap-span">Extremist is a word that trips lightly off officials’ tongues. It is often used to describe behaviour that in many other countries would be regarded simply as lass="word-wrap-span">devout. lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims in the rest of lass="word-wrap-span">China may not suffer the Uighurs’ terrible fate, lass="word-wrap-span">But they have reason to be nervous.

eg2: After a few minutes our eyes got used to the darkness.
